title: Causal effects of cardiovascular risk factors on onset of major age-related diseases: A time-to-event Mendelian randomization study
author: He
author_address: Erwin Mill Building, 2024 W. Main St., Durham, NC 27705, USA
hypothesis: Effect of BMI on age related diseases
rationale: Elucidating the causal effects of common intermediate risk factors on the onset of age-related diseases is indispensable for developing prevention and intervention procedures.
exposure_n_difference_reason: One-sample where they got exposure SNPs from external GWAS
exposure_genotyping_dataset: 1000 Genomes Project Phase I reference panel
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Also conducted sensitivity analyses: Leave-one out, plus analysis where birth cohort, sex, education level, smoking and alcohol consumption history up to the enrollment were included as covariates
IV_strength: Polygenic score was significantly (p < 0.05) as- sociated with its risk factor
replication_subsetting: Performed cohort specific MR plus MR on meta-analysed cohorts
limitations_overall: The definitions of the diseases and criteria of diagnosis may vary across these five cohorts
limitations_pleiotropy: Some observed causal associations can be attributed to pleiotropic effects of some genetic variations
limitations_statistical_power: the constructed polygenic scores can only explain a small proportion of the variance of the intermediate risk factors, which may limits the statistical power to detect the causal effects, the numbers of cases for some diseases are small, so there might be no sufficient statistical power to detect the causal effect for these diseases.

title: Causal associations between risk factors and common diseases inferred from GWAS summary data
author: Zhu
author_address: Institute for Molecular Bioscience, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia
hypothesis: Method paper: Effect of body mass index and waits hip ratio adjusted for body mass index on 22 traits and a disease count trait
rationale: We develop a method (HEIDI-outlier) to detect and eliminate genetic instruments that have apparent pleiotropic effects on both risk factor and disease, and another method (multi-trait-based conditional and joint analysis, or mtCOJO) to estimate the effect of a risk factor on disease conditioning on other risk factors. All methods developed in this study only require summary-level data (with LD between genetic variants from a reference sample with individual-level data), providing a great flexibility to integrate data from multiple studies.
exposure_pleiotropy: We propose a method (called HEIDI-outlier) to detect pleiotropic SNPs at which the estimates of bxy are significantly different from expected under a causal model, and remove them from the GSMR analysis (Methods).
exposure_HWE: We cleaned the GERA genotype data using the standard quality control (QC) filters (excluding SNPs with missing rate ≥0.02, Hardy–Weinber equilibrium test P-value ≤ 1 × 10−6 or minor allele count < 1, and removing individuals with missing rate ≥0.02), and imputed the genotype data to the 1000G using IMPUTE2.
n_SNP_difference_reason: Probably used all ancestries GWAS not EU as stated, plus use of HEIDI-outlier detection
power_calculation_how: We simulated 1,000 independent SNPs from a binomial distribution z ~B(2,f). We then generated x and y under the assumption that x has a causal effect ton y, using the same method as above with 7'" 2 = 0.6, 7"# 2 = 0.005, n1 =	50,000	and n2 = 20,000. We conducted analyses using GSMR,	MR-Egger1, MR-IVW2,	generalized MR-IVW3, and the Pickrell methods4 based on a random	subset	of the	genome-wide	significant SNPs associated with x, the	number of instruments	m ~U(10,mt) where mt is the total number of genome-wide	significant SNPs. We  ran the simulations with	10,000	replicates.
limitations_overall: there are several caveats in interpreting the GSMR results. First, if the exposure is a composite trait that comprises multiple sub-phenotypes, we could not rule out the possibility that the effect of exposure on disease is driven by one of the sub-phenotypes. Second, the effect of a risk factor on disease can be non-linear. Fourth, our analyses ignored age-specific and sex-specific effects because of the lack of data from age- and sex-stratified analyses.
limitations_pleiotropy: results were not driven by pleiotropy and reverse causality. In some cases, the relationship between a risk factor and a disease could be a mixture of multiple models. the intercepts from MR-Egger (a significant deviation of the intercept from 0 is evidence for the presence of pleiotropy) were very small relative to the slopes (Supplementary Fig. 24), and there was no inflation in the test-statistics (Supplementary Fig. 24b, c), suggesting that the degree of pleiotropy was negligible if there was any.
limitations_statistical_power: Third, although we have identified a large number of associations, we would expect that associations of small effect size would be missed in our study.
